GROUPS IN ACTION
Many of the people who helped create community enthusiasm for the program and
many of those who became group organizers were persons who had participated in
previous discussion groups, set up with the assistance of the Community Education
Project. This leadership potential of the program is one of its most valuable fea¬
tures. It offers opportunities for people who have already emerged as leaders to
develop into more mature leaders and it is a way of recruiting and training leaders
for future programs.
Detailed records were kept on as many groups as it was possible to maintain
contact with. These records yield valuable information pertaining to group si^e,
method of organization which brought the groups together, quality of the discussion,
kind of meeting places, duration of the group, reasons for disintegration (where
this occurred), and other interesting aspects of the Experiment. These are summarized
briefly below.
Statistics on the groups•
In all, 97 groups were reported. Thirty-four of these emerged from the
Preview meeting. The balance (63) were organized by the County March ofDimes Com¬
mittee which saw in the Experiment a unique opportunity for building firmer ties -
during the dormant period of the Committee’s work - among members of March ofDimes
Committees in various communities throughout San Bernardino County. Statistics are
not available for the number of people who participated in these March ofDimes
groups, nor is other detailed information about them available. The data below,
therefore, stem from only those groups registered directly with the Community Educa¬
